awd_titl_txt: Conference: SODA 2023 Conference Student and Postdoc Travel Support
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports student and postdoctoral fellow attendance at the SIAM-ACM Symposium on Discrete Algorithms (SODA), to take place during January 22-25, 2023, in Florence, Italy. SODA is a major conference with broad coverage of Theory of Computing and Discrete Mathematics. SODA has a record of strongly encouraging participation by students, particularly those from under-represented groups. The conference serves as a valuable educational experience both for the technical content of the talks and for the opportunities for networking that it provides.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
The annual ACM/SIAM Symposium on Discrete Algorithms (SODA) is jointly sponsored by the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) and the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM). SODA is regarded as the leading annual research conference on discrete algorithms, and one of the three premier theoretical computer science conferences globally.

Since its inception in 1990, SODA has convened annually, typically attracting over 350 participants. The 2023 symposium, held in Florence, Italy, saw over 400 registered participants. SODA shared its venue with three specialized workshops: ALENEX (Algorithm Engineering and Experimentation Meeting), APOCS (SIAM Symposium on Algorithmic Principles of Computer Systems) and SOSA (Symposium on Simplicity in Algorithms), drawing a diverse group of international researchers. The field of algorithms is a vibrant one, characterized by robust involvement from emerging scholars and numerous student-authored papers.

This project funded 10 students, enabling them to participate in the conference. In addition, a previous NSF travel award for SODA, with Prof. Shanghua Teng from University of Southern California as the PI, supported 9 students. All supported students were graduate-level scholars from U.S. universities, who attended to present papers or posters at the conference. In addition, the conference offered those students the opportunity to engage with prominent experts in discrete algorithms and attend presentations.


Last Modified: 06/13/2024
Modified by: Piotr Indyk
